Patch Set 23:

(3 comments)

Actually I do not think it's a race problem. It's really related to the behavior in systemd:
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/11424

“Reject Set time until the NTP is fully disabled”.
that’s a good find, will add it to the commit message.
Done

By this change, it looks like we lost the "sync" of the NTP setings in systemd and phosphor-settings.
How to resolve this?
what does “sync” mean?  functionally does it change anything for the user?

The property in phosphor-settings provides the "NTP setting" on the DBus.
By "sync" I mean the bmcweb should make sure the "NTP setting" in phosphor-settings and systemd-timedated the same.
Otherwise, when bmcweb changes the NTP settings in systemd-timedated, the setting in phosphor-settingsd is not updated.

why is that bmcweb job to keep them in sync?  isn’t that the job of settings/timesyncd?

how does this work for defaults if it’s not already reading from timesyncd?

> why is that bmcweb job to keep them in sync? isn’t that the job of settings/timesyncd?

Before this change, bmcweb get/set the "NTP settings" on phosphor-settings.
phosphor-time-manager and phosphor-settings are responsible to sync the settings with systemd-timedated.
So the services like bmcweb and ipmid will only have to get/set the property on phosphor-settings, that's all.

Now with this patch, bmcweb changes the behavior and directly set the "NTP setting" to systemd-timedated, that's why I raise the comment.

> > why is that bmcweb job to keep them in sync? isn’t that the job of settings/timesyncd?
> 
> Before this change, bmcweb get/set the "NTP settings" on phosphor-settings.
> phosphor-time-manager and phosphor-settings are responsible to sync the settings with systemd-timedated.
> So the services like bmcweb and ipmid will only have to get/set the property on phosphor-settings, that's all.
> 
> Now with this patch, bmcweb changes the behavior and directly set the "NTP setting" to systemd-timedated, that's why I raise the comment.

right, but I’m not understanding why this is an issue with bmcweb?  shouldn’t phosphor time be watching for changes to timesyncd?

Also, to reask the question previously, is this problem visible to the user at all?  if not, I’m not sure it matters?

> right, but I’m not understanding why this is an issue with bmcweb? shouldn’t phosphor time be watching for changes to timesyncd?

Because in previous implementation:
* All services (ipmi/bmcweb) gets/sets the "NTP setting" on phosphor-settings service. That's all. They do not care about timedated/timesyncd.
* phosphor-settings serves the property on DBus, make sure it's serialized/de-serialized.
* phosphor-time-manager is responsible to watch the above property, and update the systemd-timedated to enable/disable NTP.


With this patch (which I think is not appropriate), bmcweb directly sets the NTP settings to systemd-timedated and skips the phosphor-settings. This causes the problem.

> Also, to reask the question previously, is this problem visible to the user at all? if not, I’m not sure it matters?

If users sets the time quickly after disabling the NTP setting, it will have an exception internally and bmcweb will return an error, which is visible to the user.
But I think this is expected behavior because it does fail to set the time at the moment.
It's the application (e.g. WebUI) who is responsible to handle the error.

> > right, but I’m not understanding why this is an issue with bmcweb? shouldn’t phosphor time be watching for changes to timesyncd?
> 
> Because in previous implementation:
> * All services (ipmi/bmcweb) gets/sets the "NTP setting" on phosphor-settings service. That's all. They do not care about timedated/timesyncd.
> * phosphor-settings serves the property on DBus, make sure it's serialized/de-serialized.
> * phosphor-time-manager is responsible to watch the above property, and update the systemd-timedated to enable/disable NTP.

Right, and having a consolidated settings daemon shows this problem where there's no way to verify something happened, or return error codes from an operation.  I'm open to other options on how to fix this, but I can't think of any that use settingsd.

> 
> 
> With this patch (which I think is not appropriate), bmcweb directly sets the NTP settings to systemd-timedated and skips the phosphor-settings. This causes the problem.

What do you think we should do instead?  Calling settings doesn't have a method to block until NTP is actually enabled, which is the behavior Redfish clients are supposed to see.  Is there a better way to fix this?

> 
> > Also, to reask the question previously, is this problem visible to the user at all? if not, I’m not sure it matters?
> 
> If users sets the time quickly after disabling the NTP setting, it will have an exception internally and bmcweb will return an error, which is visible to the user.

I tested that, and this patch doesn't show that behavior.  Can you tell me commands you're running that's showing that behavior?

> But I think this is expected behavior because it does fail to set the time at the moment.

Right, but that's the problem, this is a Rest API.  The call should block until the setting has been accepted, so the user knows they can now set the dateTime.

> It's the application (e.g. WebUI) who is responsible to handle the error.

> What do you think we should do instead? Calling settings doesn't have a method to block until NTP is actually enabled, which is the behavior Redfish clients are supposed to see. Is there a better way to fix this?

I think we should accept the behavior, deep in the issue, it's systemd that returns the error. And the application, eighter WebUI or the caller of the REST/Redfish APIs should handle the error.

> I tested that, and this patch doesn't show that behavior. Can you tell me commands you're running that's showing that behavior?

My test is described in https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/11424, it's directly calling systemd-timedated:
```
timedatectl set-ntp 1
sleep 10
timedatectl set-ntp 0
timedatectl set-time "2019-01-12"
echo $?
timedatectl set-ntp 1
timedatectl set-time "2019-01-12"
echo $?
```

Be noted that the Redfish API to enable/disable NTP eventually has the same effect of "set-ntp 1/0", and the same for "set-time".

I just tested with a recent systemd, and it loos like the systemd-timedated fixes the issue by blocking until NTP is set.


> Right, but that's the problem, this is a Rest API. The call should block until the setting has been accepted, so the user knows they can now set the dateTime.

With the above finding (systemd-timedated blocks the call to set NTP), I get your point.
Indeed we could not make it block to set NTP to phosphor-settings... We do need a solution.

Possibly phosphor-time-manager should handle it to sync the settings in phosphor-settings and systemd-timedated in both ways.

> 
> 
> > Right, but that's the problem, this is a Rest API. The call should block until the setting has been accepted, so the user knows they can now set the dateTime.
> 
> With the above finding (systemd-timedated blocks the call to set NTP), I get your point.
> Indeed we could not make it block to set NTP to phosphor-settings... We do need a solution.
> 
> Possibly phosphor-time-manager should handle it to sync the settings in phosphor-settings and systemd-timedated in both ways.

I'm not sure I understand what you're suggesting.  Is it a patch you could propose?
@Lei?

Yup, although I think we could accept the current behavior (that it returns error), it could be better to fix the issue by calling systemd-timedated directly.

@Ed could you kindly help to add some code in phosphor-time-manager to add a match to org.freedesktop.timedate1, watching the `NTP` property, and make sure it is synced with phosphor-settings?

> Yup, although I think we could accept the current behavior (that it returns error), it could be better to fix the issue by calling systemd-timedated directly.
> 
> @Ed could you kindly help to add some code in phosphor-time-manager to add a match to org.freedesktop.timedate1, watching the `NTP` property, and make sure it is synced with phosphor-settings?

It doesn't do that already?
No, currently the time-manager only watch phosphor-settings, and call systemd-timedated to update the NTP setting.
We are already working on "time-manager" to sync the settings. Will submit the patch later.

> No, currently the time-manager only watch phosphor-settings, and call systemd-timedated to update the NTP setting.

I understand now.


> We are already working on "time-manager" to sync the settings. Will submit the patch later.

Thank you;  I appreciate it.
The changes to time-manager is submitted to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-time-manager/+/70457
Should this be using ec.value?
I think it's functionally the same?  Why would ec.value() be better here?
It wasn't clear to me they are the same. I've mostly been seeing the use of ec.value in other places in the bmcweb code I've looked at recently.

For operator ==, they're not the same (as I've found recently).  Ideally we need a deeper dive into this stuff similar to:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69477

But if you look at our std::formatter overload for this, we print out ec.what() which should be more descriptive.  Even if it's not exactly what we want, we need to fix it here:
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/6f4bd2904fd231c90ee86040f067018088097715/http/logging.hpp#L31C51-L31C55

rather than in this code.
Ahh, I see. Thank you for the link and explanation. Always better to understand 'why' something is coded a particular way.
Can ntpEnabled no longer be const &?
We pass small values by value.  There's no reason to pass by const reference here.
Resolving.
Can enabled be const?
Const correctness on small values is not something we enforce at this time.
Done
LGTM.
Looks like https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-time-manager/+/70457 merged.  We can go ahead with this.  Leaving in review for a day or two to see if anyone has any objections.
